questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding lung cancer?

choices.text: It is the most common cancer in Indian men
Tobacco smoking is the most common cause
Adenocarcinoma is the most common histologic  type
It is the most common cause of cancer death

questions.solution:
The most common cancer seen in Indian men is lip and oral cavity cancer, not lung cancer.

Most common cancer:

  • In men globally- Lung cancer
  • In Indian men- Lip and oral cavity cancer
  • In women globally- Breast cancer
  • In Indian women- Breast cancer

Tobacco smoking is a primary cause of the development of lung cancer. It increases 10 fold greater risk of developing lung cancer compared to those who have never smoked.

It is the most common cause of cancer death.

Lung cancer awareness month is observed throughout November annually to raise awareness about risk reduction and treatment options. There is a lack of knowledge on lung cancer among people. It is an effort to improve outcomes for lung cancer patients across the world.

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

questions.text: What is the most common type of lung cancer in light smokers?
questions.solution:
The most common lung cancer in light smokers (<10 pack-year history) is adenocarcinoma. 

WHO classification of lung carcinomas:

The WHO classification system divides epithelial lung cancers into four major cell types:

  • Small-cell lung cancer (SCLC)
  • Non-small-cell lung carcinomas (NSCLCs)
    • Adenocarcinoma
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Large-cell carcinoma

Adenocarcinoma is most commonly seen in:

  • Lifetime non-smokers
  • Light smokers (<10 pack-years history)
  • Women
  • Younger adults (<60 years)

In smokers, the most common types are small-cell carcinoma and squamous cell carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Incidence of lung cancer according to histology

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a 35 pack-year history of smoking presented for a routine check-up. His brother was diagnosed with lung cancer at a similar age. Which of the following would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer?
questions.solution:
Low-dose CT/ thin-slice spiral chest CT would be preferred to screen him for lung cancer. He belongs to the high-risk population to develop lung cancer.

The high-risk population is individuals whose age is ≥60 years and who have a smoking history of ≥10 pack-years.

Low dose CT scans are shown to detect more lung nodules and cancers than the standard CXR in selected high-risk populations. Also, up to 85% of cancers thus detected are classified as stage I. Early staged cancers are considered potentially curable with surgical resection.

Here, the aim is to reduce medical radiation exposure as much as possible, low dose CT is effective in screening for lung cancer, and is thus preferred.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about hypertrophic osteoarthropathy?

choices.text: Platelets have a role in the development of HOA
HOA is commonly associated with lung malignancies
Skin changes are more common in secondary HOA

questions.solution:
Skin changes are more common in primary HOA, not secondary HOA. 

Hypertrophic osteoarthropathy is a condition characterized by the clubbing of the digits. In advanced stages, it is characterized by the periosteal new bone formation and synovial effusion. The exact mechanism of its development is unclear. However, platelets are said to have a role in the development of HOA via platelet-derived growth factor.

There are two types of HOA:

          Primary HOA          Secondary HOA
Inherited autosomal dominant condition

Acquired condition, secondary to

  • Lung neoplasms
  • Mesothelioma
  • Suppurative lung infections
  • Congenital heart disease
  • Thyroid acropachy
  • Inflammatory bowel disease
Skin changes like thickening, seborrhea, excessive sweating are commonly seen Skin changes are unusual
The symptoms disappear in adulthood The symptoms persist till the underlying cause is treated

questions.text: A middle-aged non-smoker presented with a dry persistent cough and hemoptysis. A CT scan showed a mass in the periphery of his right lung. A biopsy was taken, cells showed an acinar pattern with mucin formation. The cells were positive for thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A. What other feature is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the biopsy findings is suggestive of lung adenocarcinoma. It is most commonly associated with hypertrophic osteoarthropathy.

Adenocarcinomas are mainly seen in the periphery of the lung. They grow in various patterns like acinar, lepidic, papillary, micropapillary, and solid with mucin formation. Cells are positive for markers like thyroid transcription factor 1 and napsin A.

Option C: Hypercalcemia due to ectopic production of PTH-related peptide is seen in squamous cell carcinoma.

Options B and D: However, SIADH, Cushing’s syndrome, Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome are associated with small-cell lung carcinoma.

questions.text: A female patient comes with complaints of unintentional weight loss and right shoulder pain for the past 6 months. She reports that the pain radiates to her arm and is not relieved by NSAIDs. Chest X-ray is given below. Which nerve roots are likely to be compressed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the X-ray findings is suggestive of Pancoast syndrome / superior sulcus tumor. This affects the C8, T1, and T2 nerve roots.

It presents with pain that radiates to the ulnar distribution of the arm, often with the destruction of the 1st and 2nd ribs. Patients with the central or endobronchial growth of the primary tumor may present with a cough, hemoptysis, wheeze, stridor, dyspnea, or post-obstructive pneumonitis.

Regional spread can cause

  • Tracheal obstruction
  • Esophageal compression with dysphagia
  • Recurrent laryngeal paralysis with hoarseness
  • Phrenic nerve palsy with the elevation of the hemidiaphragm and dyspnea
  • Sympathetic nerve paralysis with Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhydrosis)

questions.text: A COPD patient presented to the emergency with an acute exacerbation. On evaluation, a chest X-ray revealed a solitary pulmonary nodule. Which of the following patterns of calcification would suggest a likely malignancy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Asymmetric calcification is suggestive of a malignant lesion.

       Benign lesion         Malignant lesion
Lack of growth over a period of >2 years The growth of the lesion is evident in comparison with an old X-ray

Patterns of calcification:

  • Dense central nidus
  • Multiple punctate foci
  • Bull's eye granuloma
  • Popcorn ball hamartomas

Patterns of calcification:

  • Asymmetric 
  • Lack of calcification
Associated chest symptoms are uncommon chest symptoms like cough, hemoptysis are common
Complications are uncommon Complications like atelectasis, pneumonitis, and effusion are common

questions.text: What is the treatment of choice in patients with adenocarcinoma of the lung with EGFR mutation?
questions.solution:
Adenocarcinomas with EGFR mutation are exquisitely sensitive to tyrosine kinase inhibitors of the EGFR signal pathway such as gefitinib and erlotinib.

Option A: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF.

Option B: Paclitaxel- a taxane, is a plant alkaloid and chemotherapeutic agent.

Option C: Imatinib is a tyrosine kinase inhibitor effective in the treatment of CML and GIST.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with persistent cough and hemoptysis. The intern notices that he has moon-like facies and purple striae on his abdomen. On evaluation, a chest X-ray revealed a mass in his right lung. Which of the following type of lung carcinoma could be the cause of this patient's features?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario the patient has features of Cushing's syndrome, secondary to small-cell lung cancer. This occurs due to ectopic ACTH production. It can also seen in pulmonary carcinoids.

Most effective management is treating underlying SCLC or carcinoid.

questions.text: An elderly man was rushed to the ED with confusion and multiple episodes of vomiting. His wife reported that he had increased frequency of urination and constipation for the past 3 days. He is a known case of lung cancer. ECG showed a shortened QT interval. What could be the primary cause of his symptoms?

choices.text: Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion
Ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide

questions.solution:
The primary cause of his symptoms is ectopic secretion of PTH related peptide. Lung cancers are associated with several paraneoplastic syndromes. Squamous cell lung cancer is associated with hypercalcemia due to ectopic PTH related peptide. Hypercalcemia may present as vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, increased frequency of urination, kidney stones, bone pain and shortened QT interval.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased urine output since morning. On the previous day, she received chemotherapy for her stage 4 lung cancer. On examination, she is drowsy, HR-110/min and RR-30/min.  All of the following biochemical findings can be seen in this patient except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). It is associated with hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia.

TLS is caused by the destruction of a large number of rapidly proliferating neoplastic cells. It is usually seen within 1-5 days of receiving chemotherapy. It has also been observed with the administration of glucocorticoids, letrozole, tamoxifen, rituximab and gemtuzumab. Rarely, spontaneous necrosis of malignancies causes TLS.

Clinical features:

  • Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy
  • Pruritus, renal colicky pain, oliguria
  • Muscle cramps, carpopedal spasm, tetany

Biochemical findings:

  • Hyperuricemia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypocalcemia
  • Hyperphosphatemia

Due to these biochemical changes, there is an increased risk of arrhythmias, acidosis, and acute kidney injury.

questions.text: Which of the following is not used in the management of patients with tumor lysis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Sodium bicarbonate is not recommended in the treatment of tumor lysis syndrome (TLS).

Urinary alkalinization by sodium bicarbonate decreases the solubility of xanthine, hypoxanthine, and calcium phosphate. This potentially increases the risk of intratubular crystallization.

Management of TLS includes:

  • Aggressive hydration
  • Allopurinol
  • Rasburicase - recombinant urate oxidase
  • Febuxostat - non-purine selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following patients with non-small lung carcinoma is  a suitable candidate to undergo a potentially curative surgical resection:

choices.text: 60-year-old smoker with a tumor within 2cm of carina
55-year-old non-smoker with tumor involving the main pulmonary artery
57-year old light smoker with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases

questions.solution:
Patients with ipsilateral mediastinal node metastases are suitable candidates for curative resection.

In patients with NSCLC, the following are contraindications to potentially curative resection:

  • Extra-thoracic metastases
  • Vocal cord involvement
  • Superior vena cava syndrome
  • Involvement of the main pulmonary artery
  • Cardiac tamponade
  • Phrenic nerve paralysis
  • Malignant pleural effusion
  • Tumor within 2 cm of the carina
  • Metastasis to the contralateral lung
  • Metastases to supraclavicular lymph nodes
  • Contralateral mediastinal node metastases
